hints.content: Start by identifying the positions of all the illegal goods in the string. This will help you understand where to focus your removal efforts.
Remember that you can remove cars from either end of the string or from the middle. Think about which option might be the most efficient based on the positions of the '1's.
Consider the time costs associated with each removal operation: removing from the left or right takes 1 unit of time, while removing from the middle takes 2 units. This will influence your strategy.
You can calculate the total time required to remove all illegal cars by considering different combinations of left, right, and middle removals. Try to minimize the total time.
Focus on the leftmost and rightmost positions of the illegal cars. These will dictate the minimum number of operations needed if you decide to remove cars from the ends.
If there are no '1's in the string, the answer is immediately 0. Make sure to handle this edge case early in your solution.
When calculating the time, consider scenarios where you remove cars from one end entirely before switching to the other end. This could yield a lower total time.
Think about the possibility of removing all illegal cars from the middle. If there are few illegal cars, this might be the fastest option despite the higher cost.
You might want to create a prefix sum array to keep track of the number of illegal goods as you consider removing cars from either end.
Don't forget to account for the scenario where you might remove some cars from one end and then switch to the other end. This could yield a lower total time.
When you identify the first and last occurrence of '1', calculate the time taken to remove all cars from the left up to the first '1' and from the right down to the last '1'.
Consider the time taken if you decide to remove illegal cars from the middle after clearing the ends. This could be a valid strategy depending on the distribution of '1's.
To find the minimum time, you might need to compare the total time for multiple strategies: removing from the left, removing from the right, and removing from the middle.
Make sure to handle cases where there are consecutive '1's. Removing them might be more efficient if done in bulk rather than individually.
Finally, after calculating potential times for different strategies, return the minimum time found. Ensure your solution efficiently handles the maximum constraints.

questionNotes: An empty sequence of cars is considered to have no cars containing illegal goods.
You can perform any of the three operations any number of times.
